fields.Title of Contribution: <span style="font-size:11pt;color:#0a0a0a;">Finer Measurement Scales for Induced Hydrophobicity Using the Water Droplet Penetration Test</span>
fields.Description/Abstract: The Water Droplet Penetration Test (WDPT) is commonly used in most soil water repellency<br>(SWR) research and is particularly prominent in field studies after wildfire events. Suppose a water<br>droplet does not infiltrate the soil within the first five seconds. This soil is considered to contain<br>some degree of water repellency, classified by the overall penetration time. Our results show an<br>inflection point in the plot of the height of a droplet vs. droplet penetration time during a WDPT<br>trial. This inflection point is indicative of a combination of two possible flow patterns influencing<br>droplet penetration, one governing and the other—caused by particle lift—drastically impeding the<br>infiltration rate. The reorganization of the intrinsic particle lift at the air–water interface leads to<br>contact angles hindering the expected penetration, delaying the expected infiltration rate to degrees<br>larger than a continuously flat porous hydrophobic surface would. The particle lift creates an<br>instability that can create two competing regimes, leading to two sets of water droplet penetration<br>times. The similarity among sorptivity values for coarse grains at higher hydrophobicity levels,<br>medium grains at intermediate hydrophobicity levels, and fine grains at lower hydrophobicity levels<br>suggests that interpretation of the WDPT needs to be adjusted based on grain size.
